description: From Middle French impeccable, from Latin impeccabilis (“not liable to sin”), from im- (“not”) + peccare (“to err, to sin”).

adjectives.description: impeccable (comparative more impeccable, superlative most impeccable)

entries.meaning: Perfect, without faults, flaws or errors
examples: He grew up in Norway, but he writes impeccable English.

entries.meaning: Incapable of wrongdoing or sin; immaculate
examples: It was easy for James V to imprison Lady Glamis, but actually convicting her was far more difficult; her character was impeccable and she was highly respected by all who knew her.
